posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
I know this isn’t a one-size-fits-all answer but I’m looking at a few discussions about motion control and future planning and wanted to see what the collective wisdom of the community coalesced around.

Splitting this question into at least 2 parts, one for drive trains (specifically swerve drive), and one for other manipulators (elevators, arms, linear motion, etc) I have a question.

Specifically for teams using feedback-based control loops (eg PID control in some form - set your motor to a set point (angular or distance, etc)), how do you implement those loops and controls? Also, I know this is likely to change based on if we’re controlling a drive train (swerve drive specifically) or another manipulator (eg elevator, arm, etc).

Do you use code running on the RoboRIO to manage your PID , sensors, and control loops, or do you utilize the control loops built into most of the motor controllers to manage, and why?

The background:

My team is looking into moving motor ecosystems next year. Part of that discussion is what we need/want/will-use in motor controller features. We’ve had some… colorful… results with the REV on-controller motion control in the past, and as we look to likely change going forward, is this something we should revisit, or take one of our programming mentors thoughts of “never ever on-controller”.

So we’re looking for the community’s thoughts and experiences with on and off-controller motion control and what worked for you so that we can make an informed decision in the off-season. Hopefully before tariffs send prices to the moon.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: This year, (on my request) 341 required all motors doing position or velocity control to be CTRE . Our offseason experience with Motion Magic was way better than Smart Motion. We prefer running control loops on the motor because it’s faster and avoids any overshoots due to loop overruns. CTRE ’s fused absolute encoder mode worked great on our pivot and was super easy to setup, and IMO Phoenix Tuner is much nicer to use than the Rev Hardware Client. If you’re thinking of switching, I’d go for it. But it won’t make you suddenly better, we could have achieved all the same things this season if we had used Rev motors instead. The experience was just a lot better with CTRE .

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
for position control, we plan the setpoints in the Rio and use the outboard controller for feedback, using the built in encoders.  I used to feel the way your mentor does, that outboard control isn’t as good a teacher.  but simple pid on an integrated sensor is simple, you’re not losing a lot by moving it.  we still don’t use motion magic or whatever rev’s similar thing is called, and that is for the same reason, it’s hard to learn anything from it.

one reason we want to keep the outboard layer simple is that we want to step up our sophistication with multiple axes, so all the trajectory or profile work needs to happen on the Rio using workspace coordinates, the motor controllers can’t help with that.

If you are using anything CTR, there is zero argument about whether to use their onboard control vs running it on the roborio. It has full feedfoward support (kS, kV, kA, kG) with support for both cosine gravity feedforward (for arms) and static gravity feedforward (for elevators), it has very low latency and the loop runs at 1khz on the talon, which results in smoother control and the ability to tune it more aggressively. The Motion Magic control allows for super easy motion profiling (trapezoidal or exponential) and is trivial to implement. Also, you can fully tune the PID , FF, and motion constraints on-the-fly with zero code using Phoenix Tuner X. FusedCANCoder is also very nice and works like magic. For swerve, I used the CTR swerve library which uses the exact same control requests under the hood and is very powerful. For REV stuff, I have no idea and am of no use. I hope their library gets an overhaul sometime.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: For both the swerve drive and other manipulators, we are using the CTRE FOC motor controller, but we apply different feedforward control methods depending on the mechanism. For the swerve, we used the default CTRE feedforward controller, which uses the constants Ks, Kv, and Ka. For our elevator and arm, we employ a custom feedforward algorithm that runs on the RoboRIO, in addition to using both a custom profile controller and the CTRE motion magic FOC . This custom algorithm allows us to perform more complex calculations, such as how the motion of one subsystem can affect the feedforward value of another.

We use REV stuff. The motion profiles are on the Rio, and the position and velocity setpoints are handled by the motor controllers.  This is because maxmotion did not at all work for us.  For non-motion-profiled subsystems, we do PID on the spark because it works and keeps the code simpler.

For swerve turning, we run a PID on the rio because it’s easier to connect abs encoders to there than to the spark (which requires a breakout board and stuff).  We only run feedforward on the driving motors (is this bad? our robot doesn’t follow paths very well, and I suspect this may be part of the issue).

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
truher:

outboard control isn’t as good a teacher

truher:

it’s hard to learn anything from it

Hot take: Teaching/learning is for the offseason. In season you should be using whatever is the easiest and most performant (which most of the time is outboard control w/ MotionMagic), and students should understand how they work under the hood from good off season preparation. Of course there are cases where you can’t and need to fall back to on-RIO control.

With how fast modern mechanisms move, it’s much safer to do outboard control so any RIO loop overruns don’t destroy your mechanism.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
We use CTRE motion magic for all our PID loops now

Honestly just try it out and see how it goes. All you have to do is add acceleration and cruise velocity

100% put your PIDs on the controller themselves. Faster and easier. Phoenix tuner is your friend

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: I just had a conversation about why we weren’t using the offboard controls with my programming mentor about this today. Learning the fundamentals is good and all when the time is there and when students aren’t banging their head against the wall and not really learning the fundamentals. It’s a lot more inspiring to have it work, then go back and go under the hood.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
heh, well, that’s too spicy for me.  i think getting into the details, under pressure, is kind of the whole point.

but i don’t mean to imply that what we do is best thing for everyone.  it’s just what we do.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: Important to note that you don’t have to fully switch ecosystems to get these benefits, buying all new motors is really expensive, especially when you may only have one or two mechanisms that you would want nicer software for. In that case you might want to check out the talon FXS, which should have the same software features of other CTRE devices, but it works with non- CTRE 3rd party motors.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Opinion: feed forward matters more than feed back for FRC scale, high-performance systems.

I don’t personally give two farts about what features vendors toss into their boxes. They’re nice and all, but I value a low-latency voltage control or current control far more than full in-motor motion control.

I know how my robot works, the motor doesn’t.

That’s not to say these things don’t have some usage. But if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable - not canned.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

That’s not to say these things don’t have some usage. But if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable - not canned.

I think I disagree on this. Look through the codebases of some of the top teams. A lot of them are running Motion Magic with the CTRE provided feedforwards. For really complex systems with multiple degrees of freedom and nonlinear behavior, more custom control can make sense. It worked well for teams like 6328 and 6036 in 2023, who did some advanced modeling with CasADi, but such complexity is rare. Most high-level teams hit elite performance without that level of complexity. Canned doesn’t mean low performance. It’s all about how you use the tools. A simple control scheme that works lets you spend time on things that actually improve your performance, instead of chasing 1 percent improvements that probably don’t matter in a match.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: Tbh 1323 robots have used most of the CTR out of the box features. The stuff is pretty good and I cant recommend it enough.  The vendor code especially CTR doing the heavy lifting has been amazing for us if we are talking about high performance robots.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I’m not convinced there’s a substantial perf difference between doing your profiles/feedforwards on the RIO and doing them on the controller, other than a reduction in CAN traffic.

You should definitely run feedback on the controller rather than the RIO with modern motors.

There’s no good reason in most cases not to use motion magic now that it supports all of the “standard” WPILib feedforward terms, though, so we shouldn’t be surprised to see top teams using it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable - not canned.

FWIW, 6328 has generally found an appropriate balance here by running pure feedback on motor controllers with everything else (feedforward, profiles, etc) implemented on the RIO. We’ve never used Motion Magic or CTRE ’s on-controller feedforward in competition even after switching to their ecosystem on our primary robots in 2024.

This approach has worked exceptionally well for us because it takes advantage of how each platform works best: feedback controllers benefit from a faster update rate, but profiles and feedforward benefit from higher levels of customization (especially useful when we’re frequently dealing with complex transitions between control modes or alternative FF/profile models that would be difficult or impossible to implement with vendor libraries). We’ve never found any mechanism where running a feedforward or profile faster than 50Hz makes a measurable performance difference, so there’s no point in making more work for ourselves by restricting our options unnecessarily. That applies to hardware too, since this approach means we aren’t locked to using CTRE ’s products on our development robot.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Have you had any problems with CAN bus overhead sending updates to every controller every 20ms?  This is the only real performance reason I can think to avoid RIO profiling.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: CAN utilization has never been a significant issue for us. In 2024 and 2025 we ran nearly every subsystem except the drive on the RIO bus, and in 2023 and 2022 we were using all REV hardware (so everything on the RIO bus).

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: In 2023 we ran with RIO profile, RIO feedforward, and Spark MAX PID , and had trouble with the consistency of the 20ms RIO loop, caused by the usual reasons. It made acceleration feedforwards particularly difficult/inconsistent, given that the previous loop time wasn’t even a good heuristic to use.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
This has generally been our experience as well (abet, with good enough feed forward, the feedback often matters less )

To RC’s point, something I probably should have made clearer: Just because a team heavily leverages onboard features certainly doesn’t imply that their robot isn’t high performing from a points perspective, nor that their mechanisms aren’t high performing from a controls perspective. My opinion (definitely not theory ) is only that pure onboard control logic will eventually be outperformed by custom-designed feed forward… but whether that tipping point is before or after the “turn L’s into W’s” point is very questionable to me.

That being said, I took some time to rip back through docs, since my memory and biases on this are at least a few years old.

We’ve historically been a REV ecosystem team, at least in the 2017-2025 range. Here’s really the crux of where my opinion comes from:

image 1098×523 50.1 KB

image 1098×523 50.1 KB

image 1098×523 50.1 KB

A lot of the onboard features I recall were kinda like this - Worked ok, but ultimately “write some code yourself” was the way around the limits of performance the onboard control algorithm imposed.

And, personal bias: I’m one of those people who bristles at being “sold” on things… Brand names involving “Smart” or “Magic” are the fast track to get me to distrust the thing without even looking at it. Again, that’s a personal bias (limit, if I’m being honest).

But, looking this morning at CTRE ’s docs, I think I gotta backpedal my opinion a bit more. My opinion was not informed by 2025’s reality.

image 1188×571 62 KB

image 1188×571 62 KB

image 1188×571 62 KB

This is exactly the gain set I would have hoped for for a feedforward model that covers 99.9% of FRC situations.

Lesson learned on my end to do some research before expressing an opinion. Do as I say kids, not as I do.
